questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with a history suggestive of vasculitis. A biopsy from the involved organ was sent to the pathologist, who saw granulomas in the specimen. Which of the following diseases is least likely to be responsible for the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Granulomatous inflammation is a characteristic feature of several vasculitides, but Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA) is a non-granulomatous small-vessel vasculitis.

Granulomatous Vasculitides:

These conditions do show granulomas:

  1. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) (Option A ruled out)
    1. Necrotizing granulomas of the upper/lower respiratory tract + necrotizing crescentic GN.
  2. Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) (Option B ruled out)
    1. Extravascular granulomas with tissue eosinophilia, asthma, and vasculitis.
  3. Giant cell arteritis and Takayasu arteritis (Option D ruled out)
    1. Granulomatous inflammation of large arteries with giant cells.

Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA) - Key Differentiating Feature

  • Pathology:
    • Necrotizing small vessel vasculitis WITHOUT granulomas.
    • Commonly associated with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA).
  • Clinical:
    • Pulmonary capillaritis (alveolar hemorrhage) and necrotizing crescentic GN.

questions.text: Renal biopsy from a patient with glomerulonephritis showed immunoglobulin and complement deposition. Which of the following diseases is least likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This case describes glomerulonephritis with immunoglobulin and complement deposition, which strongly suggests an immune-complex mediated vasculitis, not an ANCA-associated (pauci-immune) type.

Wegener's Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis - GPA)

  • It is a pauci-immune small vessel vasculitis.
  • There is no immune-complex deposition; renal biopsy typically shows necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis with little or no Ig/complement deposition.
  • Hence, least likely.

Conditions with immune-complex deposition):

  • Lupus vasculitis / Lupus nephritis (Option B ruled out)
    • Due to anti-dsDNA and other autoantibodies forming immune complexes.
    • Renal biopsy: "Full-house" staining (IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C1q).
  • Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis (Hepatitis C associated) (Option C ruled out)
    • Circulating cryoglobulins (IgM with rheumatoid factor activity + IgG) form immune complexes.
    • Renal biopsy: Membranoproliferative GN with immune complex deposition.
  • IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein) (Option D ruled out)
    • IgA immune complexes deposit in the mesangium and small vessels.
    • Biopsy: IgA and C3 deposition.
  • Serum sickness and cutaneous vasculitis
    • Immune complexes deposit in small vessels, often following drugs or infections.
  • Hepatitis B-associated vasculitis (classic PAN variant)
    • Immune complexes containing hepatitis B surface antigen deposit in medium-sized vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following vasculitides is characterized by the presence of anti-endothelial cell antibodies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kawasaki disease is characterized by:

  • Immune-mediated injury of medium-sized arteries (particularly coronary arteries).
  • Anti-endothelial cell antibodies and anti-smooth muscle cell antibodies are thought to play a key role in its pathogenesis.
  • This immune response leads to panvasculitis, aneurysm formation, and the risk of thrombosis.

Explanation of other options:

Wegener's Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis) (Option B): Pathogenesis: ANCA (anti-proteinase 3/c-ANCA) mediated, pauci-immune. Not associated with anti-endothelial antibodies.

Lupus Vasculitis (Option C): Pathogenesis: Immune complex deposition (anti-dsDNA, etc.) causing complement activation. No role for anti-endothelial cell antibodies.

Sarcoid Vasculitis (Option D): Caused by non-caseating granulomatous inflammation, not autoantibodies. Anti-endothelial antibodies are not involved.

questions.text: Which of the following medium vessel vasculitides is due to immune complex deposition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN) is a classic medium-vessel vasculitis caused by immune complex deposition (often linked with Hepatitis B).
  • Pathogenesis: Immune complexes deposit in vessel walls → complement activation → transmural necrotizing inflammation.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with right foot drop, hand numbness, fevers, malaise, weight loss, polymyalgia, and diffuse joint pains for 2 months. On examination, he has a temperature of 38°C. Investigations show Hb: 8.5 g/dL, ESR: 95 mm/hr, Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL, urine: blood ++, and urine microscopy: white cells & red cell casts. Which one of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has multi-system involvement:

  • Peripheral neuropathy (right foot drop, hand numbness - mononeuritis multiplex)
  • Constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, malaise)
  • Arthralgia and polymyalgia
  • Renal involvement with hematuria and RBC casts → glomerulonephritis

Key clue: The presence of red cell casts indicates a glomerular process (small vessel involvement).

Pathology of PAN:

  • PAN is a necrotizing vasculitis of small- and medium-sized muscular arteries.
  • Does not involve venules or glomeruli (so no glomerulonephritis).
  • Renal disease in PAN is due to arteritis of the renal arteries, causing ischemia, hypertension, and infarction, not glomerulonephritis.

Key features of PAN:

  • Multiple organ involvement: renal arteries (hypertension), GI (pain, infarcts), nerves (mononeuritis multiplex), skin (nodules, livedo).
  • RBC casts or red cell dysmorphic hematuria strongly suggest small-vessel vasculitis instead (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, cryoglobulinemia, lupus).
  • Pulmonary arteries are spared in PAN.

Therefore, in a patient with GN (RBC casts) and neuropathy, PAN is least likely.

Explanation of other options:

Lupus vasculitis (Option A): Small vessel vasculitis associated with SLE. Immune complex deposition causes glomerulonephritis with RBC casts.

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis (Option B): Affects small vessels. Causes glomerulonephritis, neuropathy, arthralgia, and systemic symptoms.

Cancer-associated vasculitis (Option C): Often a small vessel vasculitis with a paraneoplastic syndrome. Can present with glomerulonephritis and neuropathy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has a history of 6 months of cutaneous symptoms in the form of Raynaud's Phenomenon and livido reticularis. He has recently had a history of numbness in the hands and feet. He presents to the emergency department with testicular pain. Which of the following complications is he least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This case describes Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN):

  • Key features from the case:
    • Cutaneous findings: Raynaud's phenomenon, livedo reticularis
    • Neurological involvement: Mononeuritis multiplex (numbness in hands/feet)
    • Genitourinary involvement: Testicular pain
  • Important fact about PAN:
    • It is a medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis.
    • Pulmonary involvement is absent in PAN, so pulmonary hemorrhage is not a feature.
  • Organs commonly affected in PAN:

Explanation of other options:

Renal failure (Option B): In PAN, medium-sized renal arteries are affected by transmural necrotizing inflammation. This causes ischemia and infarctions of renal tissue, leading to hypertension and progressive renal impairment (but not glomerulonephritis).

Hepatic infarction (Option C): The hepatic arteries may be involved in PAN, causing thrombosis, aneurysms, or occlusion. This results in hepatic infarction and sometimes right upper quadrant pain with elevated liver enzymes.

CVA (Option D): When cerebral arteries are affected, PAN can cause reduced perfusion or aneurysm rupture. This leads to strokes, seizures, or altered mental status as a complication.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a history of fever of 1 week duration, along with bilateral cervical adenopathy, bilateral conjunctival congestion, erythema of the oral cavity, and desquamation, especially of the fingertips. He has evidence of myocarditis, too. He has an ESR of 100mm/1st hour, elevated CRP, and elevated liver enzymes. Which infection will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is highly suggestive of a Kawasaki-like syndrome triggered by COVID-19 (MIS-C) rather than a classical viral exanthem.

Key features in this case:

  • Fever ≥5 days
  • Bilateral conjunctival injection (no exudate)
  • Oral mucosal changes (red, cracked lips)
  • Desquamation of fingertips
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Evidence of myocarditis
  • Elevated ESR, CRP, and transaminases

These findings satisfy the 2017 American Heart Association (AHA) diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki Disease (KD).

Link with COVID-19 (MIS-C):

According to recent evidence:

  • During the COVID-19 pandemic, a multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C) has been described that mimics Kawasaki disease, but is triggered by SARS-CoV-2 infection.
  • MIS-C presents with fever, mucocutaneous signs, myocarditis or cardiogenic shock, high ESR/CRP, liver enzyme elevation, and often gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Unlike classic KD, MIS-C patients tend to be older (school-age and adolescents) and frequently require intensive care due to cardiac dysfunction.
  • SARS-CoV-2 serology or exposure history is often positive.

The child's mucocutaneous signs, desquamation, myocarditis, and inflammatory markers strongly suggest a Kawasaki-like illness (MIS-C).

  • Among the options, COVID-19 is the infection known to trigger MIS-C with these features.
  • Other viral infections (measles, rubella) can cause rash and conjunctivitis, but do not produce this combination of myocarditis and desquamation

Explanation of other options:

Chlamydia (Option A): Chlamydia infections do not cause mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome or a Kawasaki-like presentation. They typically involve the genitourinary tract or conjunctivitis/pneumonia in neonates, not myocarditis with desquamation.

Measles (Option C): Measles presents with fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and a generalized maculopapular rash. It does not cause coronary arteritis, myocarditis, fingertip desquamation, or prolonged systemic inflammation with high ESR/CRP.

Rubella (Option D): Rubella causes a mild febrile illness with a pink, discrete rash, lymphadenopathy, and arthralgia. There is no association with myocarditis, coronary aneurysms, or Kawasaki-like features.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7656130/

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of fever for 1 week. He also has cracked lips, which are painful. On examination, his eyes are red, and he has a lymph node in the cervical region. Kawasaki syndrome is suspected. Which of the following is the best treatment choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The boy presents with:

  • Fever > 5 days
  • Cracked lips (mucosal involvement)
  • Non-exudative conjunctivitis
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy

These findings meet the diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki Disease.

Diagnostic Criteria for Kawasaki Disease:

Diagnosis = Fever for ≥ 5 days plus 4 of the 5 clinical features:

C - Conjunctivitis (bilateral, non-exudative)R - Rash (polymorphous, non-vesicular)

E - Extremity changes: erythema or edema of hands/feet, later desquamation

A - Adenopathy (cervical, usually unilateral >1.5 cm)

M - Mucosal involvement (oral erythema, cracked lips, "strawberry" tongue)

Key Features:

  • 80% occur before age 5 (but can be seen in older children).
  • Complications:
    • Coronary artery aneurysms (≈25% untreated)
    • Myocarditis, pericarditis, myocardial infarction, cardiomegaly
  • Mortality: 0.5-2.8% (mainly due to cardiac complications).

Treatment:

  • IV Immunoglobulin (IVIG):
    • 2 g/kg as a single infusion over 10 hours
    • Given early to reduce the incidence of coronary artery abnormalities
  • Aspirin:
    • High dose (100 mg/kg/day for 14 days), then low dose (3-5 mg/kg/day for 6-8 weeks)
  • If giant coronary aneurysms develop:
    • Surgical interventions (bypass or reconstruction) may be required.

Explanation of other options:

Hydrocortisone (Option B): Corticosteroids are not first-line therapy for Kawasaki disease. They may be used as adjunctive therapy in refractory cases that do not respond to IVIG, but starting steroids alone delays definitive treatment and does not prevent coronary aneurysms as effectively as IVIG.

Abciximab (Option C): Abciximab is a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor used to prevent platelet aggregation during percutaneous coronary interventions. It has no role in the acute management of Kawasaki disease.

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) (Option D): LMWH is an anticoagulant used for thrombosis prevention and treatment. In Kawasaki disease, it is reserved for children who already have large coronary aneurysms or thrombosis, not for routine initial treatment.

questions.text: A young boy presents with PAN-like vasculitis. Which of the following diseases is he likely to harbor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When a young boy presents with features of PAN-like vasculitis (medium-vessel necrotizing vasculitis), the differential changes because:

  1. Classical PAN
    • Most common in middle-aged adults, especially men.
    • Often associated with Hepatitis B infection.
  2. Key Pediatric Cause - ADA2 Deficiency
    • In very young children, Adenosine deaminase 2 (ADA2) deficiency (DADA2) is a genetic cause of PAN-like vasculitis.
    • Clinical features:
      • Early-onset vasculitis
      • Recurrent ischemic strokes
      • Livedo reticularis, nodules
      • Fever, systemic inflammation
    • Caused by biallelic mutations in the ADA2 gene (formerly CECR1).
    • Treatment: Anti-TNF agents (e.g., etanercept).
  3. Other PAN-like associations:
    • Hepatitis B and C - classically in adults
    • Hairy Cell Leukemia - can cause PAN-like vasculitis in older adults (not children).

Explanation of other options:

Chronic Hepatitis B (Option A): Classical cause of PAN in adults, not in very young children.

Sarcoidosis (Option C): Causes granulomatous inflammation, not PAN-type necrotizing vasculitis.

COVID-19 (Option D): Triggers MIS-C/Kawasaki-like vasculitis, not PAN-like vasculitis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl developed pulmonary haemorrhage and subsequent acute renal failure requiring dialysis. A renal biopsy shows crescentic glomerulonephritis. Which one of the following antibodies is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pulmonary-renal syndrome refers to the combination of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (pulmonary) and glomerulonephritis (renal).

The common causes include:

  • Goodpasture's syndrome (anti-GBM antibodies)
  • ANCA-associated small-vessel vasculitis:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (c-ANCA, anti-proteinase 3)
    • Microscopic polyangiitis (p-ANCA, anti-myeloperoxidase)
    • Churg-Strauss (eosinophilic GPA, usually p-ANCA)
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis)
  • Cryoglobulinemia

In this case:

  • Presentation- Pulmonary hemorrhage + Crescentic GN → Classic pulmonary-renal syndrome.
  • Most likely antibodies-
    • Anti-GBM antibodies
    • Hallmark of Goodpasture's disease.
    • Cause linear IgG deposition along GBM, severe alveolar hemorrhage, and rapidly progressive GN.
    • If anti-GBM is given as an option, this is the most specific answer.
  • ANCA antibodies (especially anti-myeloperoxidase, p-ANCA)
    • Seen in microscopic polyangiitis, which also causes pulmonary-renal syndrome (alveolar hemorrhage + RPGN) but without upper airway involvement.
    • Chosen only when ANCA options are given and anti-GBM is not listed.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-mitochondrial (Option A): Seen in primary biliary cholangitis, not vasculitis.

Anti-nuclear (ANA) (Option C): Found in SLE, which can cause nephritis but typically has other systemic features.

Anti-phospholipid (Option C): Associated with thrombosis and pregnancy loss, not pulmonary-renal syndrome.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with chronic recurrent sinusitis and occasional haemoptysis. He has a middle lobe patchy shadowing on his chest X-ray. His creatinine is 1.40 mg/dl, and urine dipstick shows ++ protein and blood. Which test result is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has:

  • Upper respiratory tract involvement - recurrent sinusitis
  • Lower respiratory tract involvement - haemoptysis and lung infiltrates
  • Renal involvement - hematuria and proteinuria (glomerulonephritis)

This triad of ENT + lung + kidney involvement is classic for: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly Wegener's granulomatosis) - a necrotizing small-vessel vasculitis.

Key diagnostic test:

c-ANCA (anti-proteinase 3)

  • Positive in ~90% of GPA cases.
  • Very specific when this triad is present.

Explanation of other options:

Positive ANA (Option B): Seen in SLE and connective tissue diseases, not strongly associated with sinusitis and lung-kidney syndrome.

Positive Kveim test (Option C): Diagnostic for sarcoidosis, which presents with hilar lymphadenopathy and non-caseating granulomas, not glomerulonephritis.

Positive ASOT (Option D): Indicates recent streptococcal infection (e.g., post-streptococcal GN, rheumatic fever), but there's no history of pharyngitis here, and it wouldn’t explain lung lesions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with numbness and weakness of her upper and lower limbs. She developed asthma at the age of 30, which is poorly controlled with medications. On examination, she looks unwell. She has palpable purpura over her face and over her elbows and knees. On neurological examination, she has a right-sided wrist drop, and there is weakness of dorsiflexion of her right foot. Sensation is also impaired over the dorsum of her right foot. Investigations: CXR is normal. Hb 10.9 g/dLMCV 90 fl, WBC 23 x 10^9 /l, Eosinophils 12% ANCA negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key features:

  • Adult-onset asthma (at 30 yrs) - poorly controlled.
  • Palpable purpura (skin vasculitis).
  • Mononeuritis multiplex: wrist drop and foot drop with sensory loss.
  • Marked eosinophilia (12%).
  • ANCA negative (seen in up to 50% of cases).

This triad of asthma, eosinophilia, and neuropathy with cutaneous vasculitis is classic for Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA).

Pathogenesis & Hallmarks:

  • Small and medium vessel necrotizing vasculitis with granulomas and eosinophilic infiltration.
  • Typical organ involvement:
    • Lungs: Asthma, pulmonary infiltrates
    • Nerves: Mononeuritis multiplex (seen in up to 72% of cases)
    • Skin: Palpable purpura, nodules
    • Heart: Myocarditis, coronary vasculitis
    • Kidney: Less severe than GPA/MPA (rarely crescentic GN).
  • Key lab features:
    • Eosinophilia > 10% of leukocytes (often > 1000 cells/µL).
    • Elevated ESR/CRP.
    • p-ANCA (anti-MPO) is positive in ~40-50% but may be negative.

ACR Diagnostic Criteria (need ≥ 4 of 6):

  1. Asthma
  2. Eosinophilia >10%
  3. Paranasal sinusitis
  4. Pulmonary infiltrates (transient)
  5. Mononeuritis multiplex/polyneuropathy
  6. Extravascular eosinophils on biopsy

Treatment:

  • First-line: Glucocorticoids (prednisone).
  • Severe/multisystem disease (esp. cardiac): Cyclophosphamide + steroids, later switch to azathioprine or methotrexate.
  • Refractory/relapsing: Mepolizumab (anti-IL-5 biologic), Rituximab in selected cases.

Explanation of other options

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) (Option A): Also causes mononeuritis multiplex, but no asthma or eosinophilia. Classically involves medium-sized arteries → renal, GI, skin ulcers; ANCA-negative.

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) (Option C): Multisystem, but asthma/eosinophilia not part of presentation. ANA is typically positive.

Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA) (Option D): Asthma and eosinophilia present. No vasculitis, purpura, or neuropathy.

Vasculitic rash on the skin of a patient with Churg-Strauss syndrome

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a history of palpable purpura for the last 6 months. Now she has a cough and hemoptysis, and she presents with desaturation. Her investigations show Hb of 9g/dL, ESR of 100mm/ 1st hour. A biopsy of her skin lesions shows fibrinoid necrosis without granulomas. Which of the following is the most likely disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key findings in the case:

  1. Clinical features:
    • Palpable purpura for 6 months (cutaneous small vessel vasculitis).
    • Now has cough, hemoptysis, and desaturation → indicates pulmonary capillaritis / alveolar hemorrhage.
  2. Laboratory/biopsy:
    • Very high ESR (100 mm/hr) and anemia (Hb 9 g/dL) - nonspecific markers of inflammation.
    • Skin biopsy: Fibrinoid necrosis without granulomas.

Key distinguishing feature:

  • Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA) causes pauci-immune small vessel vasculitis with:
    • Necrotizing inflammation
    • No granuloma formation
    • Frequent involvement of skin, kidneys (RPGN), and lungs (pulmonary hemorrhage)
    • Associated with p-ANCA (anti-MPO).
  • Pulmonary involvement (hemoptysis/alveolar hemorrhage) is a classic feature of MPA, not PAN.

Explanation of other options:

Wegener's Granulomatosis (Option B)(Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis - GPA): Histology shows granulomas and necrotizing vasculitis. Upper respiratory tract involvement (sinusitis, nasal septum perforation) is common. Biopsy in this patient explicitly states no granulomas.

Churg-Strauss Vasculitis (Option C)(Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis - EGPA): Characterized by asthma, peripheral eosinophilia, and granulomatous vasculitis with eosinophils. None of these features is mentioned in this patient.

Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN) (Option D): PAN also shows fibrinoid necrosis without granulomas. But PAN does not involve the lungs - pulmonary hemorrhage is absent. Classically involves medium-sized arteries → kidneys, GI tract, nerves (mononeuritis multiplex).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of hemoptysis, recurrent sinusitis, and glomerulonephritis. He has multiple palpable purpurae over the skin. You are suspecting small vessel vasculitis and want to establish the diagnosis of Wegener's Granulomatosis. Which tissue biopsy would you prefer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lung biopsy has the highest diagnostic yield for confirming GPA.

In this patient, the triad of hemoptysis, recurrent sinusitis, glomerulonephritis, and palpable purpura suggests a small-vessel ANCA-associated vasculitis, specifically Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis).

To confirm GPA, histological demonstration of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis is required.

Biopsy findings in different tissues:

  • Kidney:
    • Shows pauci-immune necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis.
    • No granulomas, so it cannot distinguish GPA from MPA. (Option C ruled out)
  • Skin:
    • Shows leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
    • Non-specific; also seen in MPA, EGPA, and HSP. (Option A ruled out)
  • Upper airway (nasal/sinus biopsy):
    • Often shows granulomas or necrosis, but vasculitis is inconsistently present (false negatives are common). (Option D ruled out)
  • Lung:
    • Best site: shows both necrotizing vasculitis and granulomatous inflammation in the same sample.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female, who has been a known case of Rheumatoid Arthritis on Adalimumab for the past 1 year. She now presents with not feeling well and a feverish feeling of one month duration. She also has arthralgias. On examination, she is febrile with no organomegaly. Her chest X-ray shows multiple cavitary lesions with prominent hilar lymph nodes. A biopsy from the nodes shows necrotizing granulomas. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient is immunosuppressed due to Adalimumab (anti-TNF therapy for rheumatoid arthritis). Anti-TNF therapy significantly increases the risk of opportunistic granulomatous infections, particularly Histoplasma capsulatum.

Key clues:

  • Background: Rheumatoid arthritis on Adalimumab → immunosuppressed.
  • Symptoms: Fever and malaise for 1 month, new arthralgias.
  • Chest X-ray: Multiple cavitary lesions with prominent hilar lymphadenopathy.
  • Biopsy: Necrotizing granulomas.

Histoplasmosis is the most likely cause because:

  • Anti-TNF drugs (adalimumab, infliximab, etanercept) predispose to disseminated histoplasmosis.
  • Necrotizing granulomas + hilar lymphadenopathy are classical findings in histoplasmosis.
  • Fungal cultures or antigen testing would confirm.

Explanation of other options:

Wegener's Granulomatosis (Option A)(Granulomatosis with polyangiitis): Causes necrotizing granulomas but rarely produces prominent hilar lymphadenopathy. Often shows involvement of the upper airway, kidneys, and cavitary nodules without significant nodes.

Bronchogenic carcinoma (Option C): Can produce cavitary lesions but does not cause necrotizing granulomatous inflammation or multiple nodes with granulomas.

Sarcoidosis (Option D): Characterized by non-necrotizing granulomas and symmetric hilar lymphadenopathy. An immunosuppressed state favors infection over sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with a 6-week history of lethargy and diffuse purpuric rash. He is noted to have a right foot drop and a left ulnar nerve palsy. He complains of arthralgia but has no clinical evidence of inflammatory joint disease. Echocardiogram is unremarkable, blood cultures are negative, ESR 80 mm/hr, ANCA negative, ANA negative, rheumatoid factor strongly positive, C3 1.1 g/l (0.75 - 1.6), C4 0.03 g/l (0.14 - 0.5). Dipstick urinalysis shows blood ++. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with:

  • Diffuse purpuric rash
  • Mononeuritis multiplex (right foot drop, left ulnar palsy)
  • Arthralgia without arthritis
  • Strongly positive rheumatoid factor
  • Low C4 with normal C3
  • Hematuria with RBC casts (suggesting glomerulonephritis)

These findings fit Cryoglobulinemic Vasculitis

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis is a systemic vasculitis caused by deposition of cryoglobulins (cold-precipitable immunoglobulins), often linked to hepatitis C, lymphoproliferative disorders, or autoimmune disease.

Clinical Features

  • Palpable purpura (cutaneous vasculitis)
  • Arthralgias
  • Peripheral neuropathy (mononeuritis multiplex)
  • Glomerulonephritis - commonly, membranoproliferative

Laboratory Clues

  • Low C4 with normal C3
  • Positive rheumatoid factor (almost always present)
  • Circulating cryoglobulins (though they can be transiently absent)
  • Evidence of HCV infection should be sought

Pathogenesis

  • Formation of immune complexes (HCV antigens + IgG + monoclonal IgM RF) → deposition in vessel walls → leukocytoclastic vasculitis.

Treatment:

  • First-line: Antiviral therapy if associated with Hepatitis C.
  • For severe active disease or relapses: Rituximab ± plasmapheresis.
  • Glucocorticoids: Only transient benefit; not long-term therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Takayasu's arteritis (Option A): Large vessel vasculitis, occurs in younger women (<40 yrs); presents with limb claudication and absent pulses, not purpura, neuropathy, and hypocomplementemia.

ANA negative SLE (Option B): SLE would typically have low C3 and C4 with ANA positivity; isolated low C4 with strongly positive RF is not typical.

Culture-negative endocarditis (Option C): Would present with positive echocardiogram findings (vegetations) and embolic phenomena; here echo is normal, and there is hypocomplementemia, which suggests immune complex disease.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has complained of pain in the temples, fevers, sweats, and malaise for 4 weeks. The right side of the face was mildly swollen, and he experienced visual loss in the right eye. On examination, he had prominent and tender temporal arteries on the right. Blood tests revealed: Hb 12.5 g/dl, MCV 86 fl, WCC 12 x 10^9/L, platelets 212 x 10^9/LESR of 90 mm/hr. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 62-year-old man presents with headache localized to the temples, constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, sweats), a tender and thickened temporal artery, and acute visual loss. Laboratory findings show very high ESR (90 mm/hr). These features are classical for Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), also known as Temporal Arteritis.

Definition & Pathogenesis

  • GCA is a vasculitis of medium- and large-sized arteries, most often affecting branches of the carotid artery, including the temporal artery, but can also involve the aorta and its branches.
  • It is antigen-driven, with CD4+ T cells and macrophages releasing cytokines (IL-2, IFN-γ, IL-17) that damage the vessel wall.
  • Histology: Panarteritis with giant cells, fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina, and intimal thickening.

Clinical Features

  • Headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and tender, nodular temporal arteries.
  • Visual loss: Caused by anterior ischemic optic neuropathy due to posterior ciliary artery occlusion.
  • Systemic features: Fever, fatigue, weight loss, high ESR.
  • Up to 40-50% of patients with GCA have Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR); conversely, 10-20% of patients with PMR develop GCA.

Laboratory Findings

  • Very high ESR/CRP.
  • Normocytic, normochromic anaemia.
  • Negative RF and ANA, distinguishing it from other rheumatologic diseases.

Diagnosis

  • Temporal artery biopsy confirms the diagnosis (3-5 cm segment because lesions are patchy).
  • Ultrasound (halo sign) may assist.
  • Importantly, treatment must not be delayed for biopsy.

Treatment

  • Immediate high-dose glucocorticoids:
    • With visual symptoms: IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day for 3 days, then switch to oral.
    • Without visual symptoms: Oral prednisolone (40-60 mg/day).
  • Aspirin (81 mg daily) is recommended to reduce cranial ischemic complications.
  • Tocilizumab (anti-IL-6): A steroid-sparing agent approved for relapsing or refractory GCA.
  • Methotrexate may be considered in patients intolerant to tocilizumab.

Explanation of other options:

Pituitary tumour (Option A): Causes bitemporal hemianopia and headaches, not tender arteries or raised ESR.

Grave's disease (Option B): May have eye signs but no temporal artery tenderness or high ESR.

Paget's disease (Option C): Skull involvement causes bone pain and deformity, not vasculitis or visual loss from arteritis.

questions.text: A 78-year-old lady presents with a 5-day history of severe left temporal headache radiating from her eye to the scalp. She had also experienced jaw discomfort while eating. Which of the following drugs should be given while awaiting the results of diagnostic tests?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key clinical clues:

  • Severe temporal headache
  • Jaw claudication (ischemia of masticatory muscles)
  • Age >50 years
  • Risk of ischemic optic neuropathy → sudden, irreversible blindness if untreated

These features strongly suggest Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), a medium- and large-vessel vasculitis.

Pathogenesis and Pathology:

  • Inflammatory panarteritis with:
    • Mononuclear cell infiltrate
    • Giant cells
    • Fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina
  • Immune mechanism:
    • CD4+ T cells and macrophages (producing IFN-γ and IL-17)
    • Intimal hyperplasia → vessel occlusion

Management:

  • Immediate high-dose glucocorticoids (Prednisolone 40-60 mg/day)
    • Treatment should not be delayed for a temporal artery biopsy.
    • In vision-threatening cases: IV methylprednisolone 1 g/day for 3 days, then switch to oral steroids.
    • Biopsy remains positive up to 14 days after starting steroids.
  • Adjuncts:
    • Low-dose aspirin reduces cranial ischemic complications.
    • Tocilizumab (IL-6 inhibitor) for steroid-sparing.
    • Methotrexate may be considered in recurrent cases or steroid toxicity.

Explanation of other options:

Carbamazepine (Option A): Used for trigeminal neuralgia (nerve pain), not vasculitis.

Azathioprine (Option C): Immunosuppressant for maintenance, not first-line acute therapy.

Infliximab (Option D): Anti-TNF agent; trials show no benefit in GCA.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man has had increasingly severe, throbbing headaches for several weeks, centered on the right. There is a palpable, tender, cord-like area over his right temple. His heart rate is regular with no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Pulses are equal and full in all extremities, BP is 110/85 mmHg. A biopsy of this lesion is obtained, and histologic examination reveals a muscular artery with luminal narrowing and medial inflammation with lymphocytes, macrophages, and occasional giant cells. He improves with a course of high-dose corticosteroid therapy. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present with this disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This case is Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), also called temporal arteritis - a large- and medium-vessel granulomatous vasculitis that predominantly affects the branches of the external carotid artery, especially the temporal artery, and typically occurs in patients over 50 years of age.

Why this is GCA:

  • Age >50 years: Disease occurs almost exclusively after age 50.
  • Symptoms: New-onset temporal headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication.
  • Examination: Palpable, thickened, tender temporal artery.
  • Complication: Visual loss due to ischemic optic neuropathy (from posterior ciliary artery involvement).
  • Histology: Panarteritis with lymphocytes, macrophages, and giant cells, fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina, and intimal proliferation.
  • Response: Marked improvement with high-dose corticosteroids.

Characteristic Laboratory Findings

  • Markedly elevated ESR (often >100 mm/hr) and CRP.
  • Normochromic normocytic anemia and sometimes thrombocytosis.
  • ESR is, therefore, the best supportive laboratory finding.

In this patient, ESR = 110 mm/hr fits the disease.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-dsDNA (1:1024) (Option A): Seen in SLE, not GCA. SLE may cause headaches, but a temporal artery biopsy would not show granulomatous vasculitis.

p-ANCA (1:160) (Option C): Associated with Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA) and Churg-Strauss (EGPA). These are small-vessel vasculitides with lung/kidney involvement, not isolated temporal artery findings.

Rheumatoid factor (80 IU/mL) (Option C): Non-specific; may be mildly elevated in older age, but not diagnostic for GCA.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of pain affecting the cervical spine and both shoulders, which was preceded by pain in the lower back and both hips. Early morning stiffness lasts until lunchtime, and she feels markedly tired and weak. Investigations demonstrate a normochromic normocytic anaemia of Hb 9.8 g/dl, ESR 72 mm in the first hour, CRP 12 g/l, serum immunoglobulins and protein electrophoresis show a polyclonal increase in gamma globulins and elevated alpha 1 and alpha 2 globulins but no paraprotein band. RA factor, anti-CCP, and ANA were negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 56-year-old woman has:

  • Symmetrical proximal girdle pain: Cervical spine, shoulders, hips
  • Prolonged morning stiffness: Lasts until lunchtime
  • Systemic features: Fatigue, weakness, elevated ESR/CRP, normocytic normochromic anemia
  • Autoantibodies (RF, anti-CCP, ANA): Negative
  • Serum electrophoresis: Polyclonal increase, no paraprotein

These findings are classic for Polymyalgia Rheumatica (PMR).

Key Features of PMR:

  • Age >50 years with pain and stiffness in the shoulders, hips, neck, and back.
  • Stiffness is worst in the morning and after inactivity.
  • No true muscle weakness; CK is normal.
  • Inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) are elevated.
  • Normochromic normocytic anemia is common.
  • Dramatic response to low-dose corticosteroids (10-20 mg prednisolone).

Association with Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA):

  • 40-50% of patients with GCA have PMR.
  • 10-20% of PMR patients develop GCA.

Management:

  • Prednisone 10-20 mg/day leads to rapid improvement.
  • Monitor for symptoms of GCA (headache, visual disturbances, jaw claudication) during follow-up.

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid Arthritis (Option A): Typically involves distal small joints (MCP, PIP) with positive RF/anti-CCP. PMR affects the proximal girdle, not small joints.

Ankylosing Spondylitis (Option B): More common in younger men (<40 years). Presents with sacroiliitis, enthesitis, and HLA-B27 positivity. No high ESR/CRP without these typical findings.

Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD) (Option C): Presents with Raynaud's phenomenon, swollen hands, sclerodactyly, myositis, and anti-U1 RNP antibodies, which are absent here.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with claudication in her lower limbs. She is noted to have absent left arm pulses. The previous year, she had a small hemispheric cerebrovascular infarct. Her ESR is 100mm/hr. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key findings in the question:

  • Young female (46 years old)
  • Absent left arm pulses (pulseless upper limb)
  • Claudication in the lower limbs
  • Previous stroke
  • High ESR (100 mm/hr)

These are characteristic of Takayasu arteritis, a large-vessel vasculitis that affects the aorta and its major branches.

Chronic inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium and large arteries, with a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches (may also involve the pulmonary artery), most commonly seen in adolescent girls and young women.

Pathology

  • Panarteritis with:
    • Inflammatory mononuclear infiltrates ± giant cells.
    • Marked intimal proliferation, scarring of the media, and destruction of the elastic lamina.
    • Leads to narrowing, occlusion, post-stenotic dilatation, or aneurysm formation.
    • Vasa vasorum involvement is common.
  • Mechanism:
    • Immune-mediated (immune complexes implicated).

Clinical Features

  • Systemic phase (constitutional symptoms):
    • Malaise, fever, night sweats, arthralgias, weight loss.
  • Vascular phase:
    • Absent or diminished pulses (commonly the subclavian artery).
    • Claudication (upper or lower limbs).
    • Discrepancy in blood pressure between arms.
    • Arterial bruits.
    • Hypertension in 32-93% (due to renal artery involvement).

Investigations

  • Lab:
    • Elevated ESR and CRP, mild anemia, elevated immunoglobulins.
  • Imaging:
    • CT/MR angiography shows:
      • Irregular vessel walls
      • Stenosis
      • Post-stenotic dilation
      • Collateral circulation

Treatment

  • First line: High-dose glucocorticoids (40-60 mg prednisone/day).
  • If refractory or for steroid sparing:
    • Methotrexate (25 mg/week)
    • Anti-TNF therapy (encouraging results, but no RCTs).
    • Tocilizumab - mixed evidence; some benefit in refractory cases.
  • Surgery/angioplasty:
    • Indicated only after inflammation is controlled.

Explanation of other options:

Giant Cell Arteritis (Temporal Arteritis) (Option A): Occurs almost exclusively in patients over 50 years and typically involves branches of the carotid artery (temporal, ophthalmic), causing headache, jaw claudication, and vision loss. Upper limb pulse loss is unusual at presentation, and systemic large-vessel involvement is less common than in Takayasu.

Familial Hypercholesterolemia (Option C): Causes premature atherosclerosis with early-onset coronary artery disease and stroke due to lipid deposition. It does not cause absent pulses, asymmetric blood pressures, or a markedly raised ESR.

Coarctation of the Aorta (Option D): Usually presents in childhood or young adulthood with upper limb hypertension and radio-femoral delay due to narrowing of the descending aorta. It does not produce systemic inflammatory signs such as a high ESR and does not typically cause absent arm pulses.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with widespread palpable purpura over the legs and buttocks. She has abdominal pains and is noted to have blood and protein in the urine dipstick. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical presentation:

  • A 10-15-year-old child with palpable purpura over the buttocks and legs, abdominal pain, and hematuria/proteinuria strongly suggests IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein).
  • The triad of skin involvement, gastrointestinal pain, and renal findings is classical.

Pathogenesis:

  • IgA immune complex deposition in small vessels causes leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
  • Often follows upper respiratory infections or other antigenic triggers.

Characteristic features:

  • Skin: Non-thrombocytopenic palpable purpura, most common on buttocks/lower extremities.
  • GI: Colicky abdominal pain (seen in 70% of cases), may present with blood/mucus in stool or intussusception.
  • Joints: Arthralgias or mild arthritis without erosions.
  • Kidney: Microscopic hematuria, proteinuria; rarely, progressive glomerulonephritis (RBC casts).

Diagnosis:

  • Largely clinical; skin biopsy (if needed) shows IgA and C3 deposition.
  • Platelets are normal (distinguishing it from thrombocytopenic purpura).

Treatment:

  • Supportive in most children (excellent prognosis; <5% progress to ESRD).
  • Steroids (prednisone 1 mg/kg/day) can be used for severe abdominal pain or edema, but do not alter the skin or kidney outcome.

Explanation of other options:

Juvenile Dermatomyositis (Option A): Presents with proximal muscle weakness and characteristic heliotrope rash and Gottron papules, not with palpable purpura. Renal involvement and colicky abdominal pain are not features.

Juvenile Chronic Arthritis (Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis) (Option B): Manifests with persistent arthritis (joint swelling and stiffness) and may have systemic symptoms like fever and rash, but purpura and renal findings are not seen. The rash, when present, is typically an evanescent salmon-pink rash.

Rheumatoid Arthritis (Option D): RA in children (juvenile form) also presents with chronic arthritis and joint deformities, but does not cause palpable purpura or hematuria/proteinuria. The patient's predominant presentation here is vasculitis, not joint disease.

questions.text: A 54-year-old homeless man presents with a six-month history of periodic knee pains and aching legs. These have been occurring monthly, and episodes last up to two weeks. He has noticed a 'bumpy' rash on his lower legs and complains of feeling more tired than usual. He has no significant past medical history. He is currently reporting to a pharmacy daily for methadone. Clinical examination demonstrated: pulse 88 (regular), normal heart sounds and chest sounds, painful but full active range of knee motion, and palpable purpura to the lower extremities. Blood tests revealed; Hb 11.9 g/dL(1C-18)MCV 93fL(80 - 96)WCC 9.8 x 109/L (4 - 11)ALT 150 iu/L(5 - 35)AST 90 iu/L(1 - 31)Complement C4 64 mg/dL(75-135) Which test is most likely to assist you in the management of this man's illness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This presentation is most consistent with Hepatitis C-associated mixed cryoglobulinemic vasculitis, and therefore, Hepatitis C serology is the key test to confirm the underlying cause and guide management.

Key Findings:

  1. Risk factors:
    • Homeless male on methadone → suggests a history of IV drug use, which predisposes to blood-borne infections (Hepatitis C, HIV).
  2. Clinical features:
    • Recurrent non-erosive joint pain (arthralgia)
    • Palpable purpura on the lower legs
    • Fatigue and systemic symptoms
  3. Investigations:
    • Elevated liver enzymes (ALT 150, AST 90) → suggests chronic viral hepatitis.
    • Low complement C4 (hypocomplementemia) → classic for mixed cryoglobulinemia.
    • Normal C3 (not given as low).
    • Mild normocytic anemia.

Pathogenesis

  • Hepatitis C infection chronically stimulates B-cells → production of cryoglobulins (immune complexes) → deposition in small vessels → palpable purpura, non-erosive arthralgia, MPGN, neuropathy.
  • Key lab clues:
    • Low C4 (with normal/near-normal C3).
    • Positive Rheumatoid Factor (not given but common).
    • Elevated transaminases.

Why Hepatitis C serology is most important:

  • Confirms the underlying etiology of cryoglobulinemia.
  • Guided treatment: Antiviral therapy (e.g., direct-acting antivirals) is central to management.
  • Cryoglobulin testing detects immune complexes but does not guide treatment unless the cause (e.g., Hepatitis C) is identified.

Explanation of other options:

ANA (Option A): Used for SLE; presentation (palpable purpura + low C4 + high liver enzymes) does not fit SLE.

Anti-CCP (Option B): Specific for rheumatoid arthritis; this patient has non-erosive, intermittent arthritis and a vasculitic rash.

Cryoglobulin serology (Option C): Would detect cryoglobulins but does not address the underlying cause; most mixed cryoglobulinemia is Hepatitis C-related, so the more useful test is HCV serology.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with chronic hepatitis C presents with a six-week history of extensive non-blanching rash on her legs. She has also developed swelling and stiffness in the MCP and IP joints. On examination, there is pitting oedema, her BP is 130/90 mm Hg, and urine dipstick shows 3+ proteins. Recent blood tests are as follows: Haemoglobin 13.1g/dl(11.5 - 16.5 g/dL)WBC 8.2 x 10^9/L (4 - 11 x 10^9/L)Neutrophils 5.1 x 10^9/L (1.5 - 7 x 10^9/L)Platelets 280 x 10^9/L (150 - 400 x 10^9/L)ESR 48 mm/hr(0 - 30 mm/1st hr)Bilirubin 2 mg/dlAlbumin 2.5 g/dL(3.7 - 4.9 g/dL)Alkaline phosphatase 160 U/L(45 - 105 U/L (over 14 years))Rheumatoid factor positive (1:2048) (< 30 k IU/L)ALT 58 IU/L. Urea, electrolytes, and creatinine: Normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mixed cryoglobulinemia manifests as

Purpura

Cutaneous ulcers

Polyneuropathy

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis and non-erosive polyarthralgia is associated with hepatitis C.

Laboratory investigations show positive rheumatoid factor, low C4, active urine sediments, and type II or III serum cryoglobulins. There may be axonal polyneuropathy.

Active urinary sediment suggests the presence of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Polyarteritis nodosa is associated with hepatitis B.
